in New York in colonial times
who won acquittal on sedition
charges in case that established
the principle that the press is
free to criticize the government.


Mr.. Heiskell opposed Arkan-
sas Governor Orval E. Faubus
during the widely publicized tur-
moil over desegregation of Little
Rocks public schools. His news
paper was boycotted with the
resultant loss of some 81 mil
lion in circulation "l1 advertis-
ing revenue.


The following year however,
the Gazette won a Pulitzer gold
medal for meritorious public
service.

81 YR. OLD EDITOR
TO BE HONORED

TUCSON, Arizona John Meth
erland Heiskell, o2-year-old edi-
tor of the Arkansas Gazette has
been named winner of the 18th
annual John Peter Zenger Award.
Heiskell and his paper suffered
heavy financial losses when he
opposed school segregation dur
ing the 1857 controversy in Lit
tie Rock, Ark.


The award, given by the Uni
versity of Arizona here, will be
formally presented to the Arkan-
sas editor January9 at the annual
convention here of the Arizona
Newspaper Publishers Associa-
tion. Zenger, after whom the
award Is named was a printer

CHICAGO. Ill = Chicago opened
wide its heart to receive Amer
ica's beloved Marian Anderson,
singer who sang a concert on
her farewell tour in Orchestra
hall Sunday to an overwhelming
audience of nearly 5000 with
Franz Rupp accompanying her at
the piano.

NEW YORK CTTY-The way the
Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker sees it,
someone is trying to even up
scores with him for his militant
civil rights record.


That is the reason, Rev. Walk
er opines. that newspaper reports
have been published charging him
with failing to file tax returns
from 1858 to 1861.


Former executive assistant to
the Rev. DR.. Martin Luther King,
world famed civil rights leader,
Rev. Walker is now on a two
year leave of absence from Kings
organization, SCLC, and working
in Yonkers as a marketing con-
sultant with Educational Herr
tage, a publishing company pro-
ducing Negro encyclopedia.


Rev. Walker denied a claim
allegedly made by Internal Rev
enue in Atlanta that he had failed
to file.

The Anderson concert was
significant event for the windy
city because here was an artist
this city had sheltered and nur-
tured in the early days of her
career when she needed help
most. A scholarship awardedher
by The National Association of
Negro Musicians paved the way
for greater opportunities.
